reviewText:
Medieval: Total War is one of those strategic game, where the aim is to conquer the world. It has the dated charm of the 00's and lacks the impressive graphics of later Total War games, but it is my contention that this game is a great one in its own right.

One might think that the only reason to get the game is for nostagia's sake. And there is no denying that a significant percentage of the purchases will probably come from old players. The advantage of this copy compared to the old one that you might still own is that it is now compatible mith modern operating systems. I am personnally using windows 7 and have had no problems playing a few turns in the campaign and winning a custom battle. Moreover, the price tag is quite reasonable.

The game is 13 years old and the graphics are no longer up to today's standards. They still have a certain charm to them and it does not prevent having fun at all. In addition, the game offers 4 different campaigns - 3 European ones, set at different starting dates and a viking campaign set in the Britich Isles, whichs allows considerable replayability.

However, the game is much more than just a means to satiate your nostalgia, which is why I spent hundreds of hours playing it in the first place, more than ten years ago. The game is different from all Total War games that would follow (only bearing resamblance to its predecessor Shogun), mainly regarding the campaign map. It uses a Risk-like campaign map, which means that movement is much more restrained. This allows for totally different campaign dynamics and really gives a fresh feel to the campaign, at least for Total War veterans who are not used to this campaign-style. One of the main advantages of this system is that it is much simpler and the AI can therefore cope with it significantly better than with the totally open campaign of later iterations. This makes the campaign both fun and challenging, as defeat becomes a very real possibility.

Regarding battles, the principles applied in later iterations were already present in Medieval and the most interesting feature is that there are lots of historical battles, grouped in different historical campaigns (100 years war, Saladin, Lionheart,...). Playing those historical campaigns gives a nice sense of progression and is quite rare in later iterations (Fall of the Samurai being the only later game to have a historical campaign).

After explaining the pros and cons of the game, I hope that I could convey the particular feel of this game, and I can only commend this game to those who want a different Total War experience!

reviewText:
Medieval: Total War is a game I spend hundreds of hours on in my gaming youth. For the time, the graphics were amazing (and are still charming today), while the game-play was addicting. Up until a few months ago, I still had the disc version installed on my computer, and knew a number of tricks and hax to get the game to function without crashing every other turn. So when I saw that the game had been released on Steam with the promise of new patches and upgrades, I had to get it and see for myself if there were any improvements.

So how does the game run? Very well. Load times are massively reduced. Ten hours in, and not a single crash (auto-save is enabled). Wide-screen resolutions actually work; the game plays flawlessly in 1080p . A slight downside: the on-screen text gets REALLY small at higher resolutions; the game also ran flawlessly in 1440p, but the text was so tiny I was worried about eye-strain. Also strange: if you select “wide screen” in the options menu, the battles play out with black bars at the top and bottom of the screen. If you select “full screen”, the black bars are gone and the battlefield takes up the entire screen (which is what I wanted anyway).

The Medieval: Total War is one of the classic strategy titles for a reason. You'll build your armies and manage your economy, while trying to establish an empire – one faction to rule them all! There are a lot things Medieval: Total War does that the sequels (starting with the very next Total War game, the first Rome TW) simply don't have. Like faction respawning. Think you've wiped a faction from the map? Not likely; the next rebellion  may spawn several massive armies in your heartland with a message like “A long-lost heir from a faction presumed destroyed is trying to reclaim his throne.” Even better, if a rival destroyed a faction, send in spies and assassins to wreak havoc and cause a revolt, in the hopes of the faction respawning in your enemy's territory, giving you the perfect opportunity to strike. Other factions emerge at specific times, like the Burgundians and the Swiss; each field some new troop types that cause a variety of problems. Putting an effort into building trading routes pays dividends, awarding huge amounts of cash if you can protect your trading routes. Conserving money and investing in the right technologies at the right time can produce an unstoppable army; spending too much too soon may give you powerful troops, but no cash to pay them. Loyalty will decline, and the troops might even rebel. Failing a crusade or jihad, or your king dying will seriously impact army loyalty - at least until the new king shows himself to be a strong leader.

The battle AI is actually smart, trying to flank with cavalry, or keep you at a distance to pelt your army to death with arrows. Say you've struggled to beat most of an Egyptian army; there's just four more units located on the other side of that sand dune. Your now-exhausted troops trudge up to the ridge, ready to turn and run at the first surprise, and... those four units are all Ghulam Bodyguards. Well, you're screwed. Your own greed will defeat you time and again in battle. Balance your armies, choose good defensive positions, attack with careful timing, and send your troops in pursuit of a fleeing enemy with prudence. A sudden influx of enemy reinforcements could rout the units you sent in pursuit, which could turn the tide of the battle against you.

The Steam version of Medieval: Total War is exactly the game that I remember from before, now with faster load times and wide-screen resolutions. This might be my nostalgia talking, but the game stands as one of the greatest and best Total War titles, despite its age. Don't hesitate to grab this one.

QUICK NOTE ON PERFORMANCE: I have Windows 7, intel CPU and an AMD graphics card, which seems to be the best PC spec for the game. I haven't experienced a single bug or crash with this setup.

Medieval 1 is, for me, the best of the Total War series. The risk-style campaign map offers the best strategising compared to the 3D campaign maps in the follow up games, which the AI never managed to properly make use of.

Here, it is a cutthroat, tense battle of wills at each end of game turn as you wait to see if a faction sends their giant army stacks into your territories. Many tough decisions have to be made when it comes to balancing your forces. It's perfectly streamlined and never gets bogged down.

The battles, too, are superior to the follow up games. Units take their time climbing hills, slowly whittling eachother down in combat, allowing proper tactical changes during battles. You truly feel like a general directing a battle, unlike the 5 minute mass brawls of Rome/Med2 which ended up resembling some Benny Hill inspired, fast forwarded mess.

The game engenders that feeling of intrigue and epic storytelling more than any other TW.

So, if you feel your PC setup can get it running properly, I heartily recommend picking this up. It's arguably one of the very best PC games of all time and still holds up remarkably well.

reviewText:
This game is unlike all the others in the Total War series, so calling it the best would be like saying an apple is better than an orange. But by the same coin, I don't think there is another game that I can say is better than it.

What the original MTW does really well is the campaign. I don't care much for the battles, as later Total War games have greatly improved on them (particularly the first Rome), so I personally never do battles manually in MTW. But the beauty of the game is that it is a lot of fun without doing the battles at all. I am sure that there are many who love the battles, which is fine, but this review is from the perspective of a pure campaigner.

One reason you can skip battles is that the autocomplete is very fair - if you have the superior army, you will win, and casualties will be reasonable. If you have similar armies, it is a dice toss. This is different from later Total War games, where even a battle between 1000 men against 100 men needs to be resolved manually, because higher difficulty settings will attribute unreasonable losses against the human player, even though the battle would be trivial and boring to do manually.

Because of the fair autocomplete, you do not need to do dozens of repetive unbalanced battles, which seem to bog down each successive Total War Game more than the last. MTW is much more fast-paced, and if you do want to manually complete battles, you can focus just on the interesting ones. If you don't want to autocomplete battles, then the game becomes one of pure campaign strategy, which is fast-paced due to the lack of interruptions from manual battles.

Adding to the fast pace of the game is the fact that you are moving armies from province to province in the same way that you would move around pieces in checkers. It is not as realistic as in later Total War Games, but it makes things a lot faster - no slow 20-turn marches across the Russian Steppes to take a minor settlement, as in newer TW games. And you are less likely to return to a save file if you get defeated, because you don't need to go through the same tedium again.

Another aspect that makes the game fast is that you can move an army from a province with a port to any province in the world that you have an uncontested line of naval control too. This greatly speeds up the endgame, and gives you the most tangible reward for naval power in any TW game. There are some kinks in the mechanic (I'll talk about them later), but it is a fun and interesting mechanic if nothing else.

Ok, so what I have gotten to so far is that the game is designed to be fast-paced, and playable just on the campaign map. The map itself has a very clean and attractive aesthetic for what it is, and I never bore of staring at it while I play. The music is excellent. There is a well-developed building tree, and a very good economic structure. It is balanced enough so that a good player playing at the appropriate difficulty setting for his skill will be neither too broke nor unreasonably wealthy.

There is a large variety of units that are available, though you will probably focus on recruiting a particular type of mid-range infantry if you are concentrating on auto-battles. This is a possible weakness of the game, because you are essentially building basic armies in the same way you do in Risk, since the auto-complete give little consideration for spear-beats-horse type combinations. But this doesn't matter much if you are not doing manual battles, and it is fun experimenting with the building trees of different factions to determine the most cost-effective and technically feasible main battle infantry to try to build recruiting buildings for.

What is perhaps best about the game is that the weighting of the difficulty settings is done very well. An amatuer player on medium can probably complete the campaign in just a bit more time than an experienced player can complete expert difficulty. In many other games, increasing difficulty means slapping more health bars onto the AI, or removing your resources, or do any one of many things that just makes the game more annoying. I think (correct me if I'm wrong) that MTW simply gives more resources to the enemies, so that they can expand more aggressively. They feel more and more human, so it is more satisfying to overcome them.

There are some things about the game that will really put some people off at first. In particular, it is notorious for having a number of mechanisms that can put your whole empire into rebellion with little notice, especially near the end of the game. You will have everything in hand, then you will realize that half your empire wants to rebel (you hold shift for a summary of public order, and half the map has gone from green to red!). You try to settle things down, but a number of provinces rebel. But many of the rebels are not ordinary rebels - they are factions you have defeated reemerging, usually with 4 massive armies that are going to need a concerted effort to defeat. In an instant, all is lost, and it is frustrating because it seems random.

It isn't random though. An expert player knows all the tricks. The main culprit is usually your king's influence. The closer the line of communication between your king and a province, the higher the public order. Influence can take a shortcut across oceans if you have a pure line of naval communication. So if you control all the seas and your king is at a province with a port, there will be a big public order boost almost everywhere. But if that influence is broken for a second, everything can fall apart. If your king dies, the heir will pop up in your most important city, which may no longer be your capital. So if you capture Constantinople and it has no port, then your king dies, your heir will probably appear there, and you will have a public order crisis until you can get him somewhere better. Another possibility is that you start a war with a small nation that has a navy. Even if your navy is vastly superior, if there are any contested waters breaking your line of communication, expect rebellions. So if Spain has one ship in the straights of Gibralter and you have a dozen when war breaks out, you are still going to have rebellions at least until the next turn when you sink that ship. And since they might be building another ship that will appear next turn, or maybe the ship they have is fast and they intend to move it to the next province before you can hit it, it might not be so simple to solve this problem. You can also have the same naval problems if a storm sinks one of your ships, so it's always good to have at least 2 in every sea. A final problem too is that some factions have a tendency to split in two when an heir rebels, even if your empire is healthy, so you may want to keep your heirs in the same army as your king, just to be safe.

The above issues are frustrating, but there are always ways around them. Some of them are a little cheap (I shamelessly go back to a saved game when I lose too many naval battles, because they are more luck-based, and I don't want it to affect the main game), but most of them are just being careful (keep your king in a good position, don't overextend your navy, aggresively take down nations with strong navies, etc), and there is a certain degree of pride when you can overcome all these challenges.

At the end of the day, this is an excellent game. It's challenging and fair, and it's one that I never tire of. I start playing this game again at least once per year, every year, and I am glad that it is finally here on Steam!

The elephant in the room of course, is the ancient graphics. All troopers in the 3D battlefield are 2D sprites, but always changing/angleing to the camera to give the illusion it's all 3D. Overall, I think this is a fun game, and well worth the few dollars.

reviewText:
This game is unlike all the others in the Total War series, so calling it the best would be like saying an apple is better than an orange. But by the same coin, I don't think there is another game that I can say is better than it.

What the original MTW does really well is the campaign. I don't care much for the battles, as later Total War games have greatly improved on them (particularly the first Rome), so I personally never do battles manually in MTW. But the beauty of the game is that it is a lot of fun without doing the battles at all. I am sure that there are many who love the battles, which is fine, but this review is from the perspective of a pure campaigner.

One reason you can skip battles is that the autocomplete is very fair - if you have the superior army, you will win, and casualties will be reasonable. If you have similar armies, it is a dice toss. This is different from later Total War games, where even a battle between 1000 men against 100 men needs to be resolved manually, because higher difficulty settings will attribute unreasonable losses against the human player, even though the battle would be trivial and boring to do manually.

Because of the fair autocomplete, you do not need to do dozens of repetive unbalanced battles, which seem to bog down each successive Total War Game more than the last. MTW is much more fast-paced, and if you do want to manually complete battles, you can focus just on the interesting ones. If you don't want to autocomplete battles, then the game becomes one of pure campaign strategy, which is fast-paced due to the lack of interruptions from manual battles.

Adding to the fast pace of the game is the fact that you are moving armies from province to province in the same way that you would move around pieces in checkers. It is not as realistic as in later Total War Games, but it makes things a lot faster - no slow 20-turn marches across the Russian Steppes to take a minor settlement, as in newer TW games. And you are less likely to return to a save file if you get defeated, because you don't need to go through the same tedium again.

Another aspect that makes the game fast is that you can move an army from a province with a port to any province in the world that you have an uncontested line of naval control too. This greatly speeds up the endgame, and gives you the most tangible reward for naval power in any TW game. There are some kinks in the mechanic (I'll talk about them later), but it is a fun and interesting mechanic if nothing else.

Ok, so what I have gotten to so far is that the game is designed to be fast-paced, and playable just on the campaign map. The map itself has a very clean and attractive aesthetic for what it is, and I never bore of staring at it while I play. The music is excellent. There is a well-developed building tree, and a very good economic structure. It is balanced enough so that a good player playing at the appropriate difficulty setting for his skill will be neither too broke nor unreasonably wealthy.

There is a large variety of units that are available, though you will probably focus on recruiting a particular type of mid-range infantry if you are concentrating on auto-battles. This is a possible weakness of the game, because you are essentially building basic armies in the same way you do in Risk, since the auto-complete give little consideration for spear-beats-horse type combinations. But this doesn't matter much if you are not doing manual battles, and it is fun experimenting with the building trees of different factions to determine the most cost-effective and technically feasible main battle infantry to try to build recruiting buildings for.

What is perhaps best about the game is that the weighting of the difficulty settings is done very well. An amatuer player on medium can probably complete the campaign in just a bit more time than an experienced player can complete expert difficulty. In many other games, increasing difficulty means slapping more health bars onto the AI, or removing your resources, or do any one of many things that just makes the game more annoying. I think (correct me if I'm wrong) that MTW simply gives more resources to the enemies, so that they can expand more aggressively. They feel more and more human, so it is more satisfying to overcome them.

There are some things about the game that will really put some people off at first. In particular, it is notorious for having a number of mechanisms that can put your whole empire into rebellion with little notice, especially near the end of the game. You will have everything in hand, then you will realize that half your empire wants to rebel (you hold shift for a summary of public order, and half the map has gone from green to red!). You try to settle things down, but a number of provinces rebel. But many of the rebels are not ordinary rebels - they are factions you have defeated reemerging, usually with 4 massive armies that are going to need a concerted effort to defeat. In an instant, all is lost, and it is frustrating because it seems random.

It isn't random though. An expert player knows all the tricks. The main culprit is usually your king's influence. The closer the line of communication between your king and a province, the higher the public order. Influence can take a shortcut across oceans if you have a pure line of naval communication. So if you control all the seas and your king is at a province with a port, there will be a big public order boost almost everywhere. But if that influence is broken for a second, everything can fall apart. If your king dies, the heir will pop up in your most important city, which may no longer be your capital. So if you capture Constantinople and it has no port, then your king dies, your heir will probably appear there, and you will have a public order crisis until you can get him somewhere better. Another possibility is that you start a war with a small nation that has a navy. Even if your navy is vastly superior, if there are any contested waters breaking your line of communication, expect rebellions. So if Spain has one ship in the straights of Gibralter and you have a dozen when war breaks out, you are still going to have rebellions at least until the next turn when you sink that ship. And since they might be building another ship that will appear next turn, or maybe the ship they have is fast and they intend to move it to the next province before you can hit it, it might not be so simple to solve this problem. You can also have the same naval problems if a storm sinks one of your ships, so it's always good to have at least 2 in every sea. A final problem too is that some factions have a tendency to split in two when an heir rebels, even if your empire is healthy, so you may want to keep your heirs in the same army as your king, just to be safe.

The above issues are frustrating, but there are always ways around them. Some of them are a little cheap (I shamelessly go back to a saved game when I lose too many naval battles, because they are more luck-based, and I don't want it to affect the main game), but most of them are just being careful (keep your king in a good position, don't overextend your navy, aggresively take down nations with strong navies, etc), and there is a certain degree of pride when you can overcome all these challenges.

At the end of the day, this is an excellent game. It's challenging and fair, and it's one that I never tire of. I start playing this game again at least once per year, every year, and I am glad that it is finally here on Steam!

Excellent purchase. Zero problems with the game. I just put the resolution up in the graphics menu and that was that. The AI is one of the best in the Total War games, especially with the introduction of the Vikings in Viking Invasion. The atmosphere is brooding and the contours of the land are very nice on the eye. The units look a bit dated now but once you get fighting then you forget that.

You can easily get beaten by the AI on the batttlefield as you come across superior troops, more men, and crazy berserkers. It can be a little arcade-like at times with 300 peasants fighting 6 berserkers but you need to apply good battlefield strategy to overcome these problems...

The enemy AI is very reactive - unlike in Rome/Medieval 2 whereby troops will just sit and take archer fire, in this game you will get charged off the field more often than not as the enemy tries to counter you quite forceably. Very good fun and every battle can be significant and is often decided in one moment..

PS The other great thing about the game is how you can fight two different armies on the battlefield like the Vikings and the rebels. Trying to position yourself in the right way while taking on two different enemies is really exciting. You often don't have a clue how the battles are going to turn out.
